meeting_annotations.speaker: Shaama M Sharada
meeting_annotations.transcript: temperatures is by using these very approximate rate theories, right? We for for almost a century now we've been using transition state theory and assuming that all of these modes are harmonic. And we all implicitly know that there are deficiencies to this. And the the thing though is that like more advanced more accurate rate theories exist. So there's variational theories, there are semi-classical theories, all of them exist, we just don't use them because they're too expensive. So I think there is definitely room for finding ways in which we can make these more expensive theories more tractable. I think a lot of advances in machine learning, signal processing, all of these can be applied to like quantum chemistry to make all of this happen and and make those more cost effective. And and therefore make quantum chemistry predictions of rates more accurate. We generally throw out our rate coefficient predictions because we know that they're quite meaningless. We only compare barriers, we only look at potential energy surfaces. But I think there's room for rate predictions, accurate tunneling contribution calculations and so on. Like all of those sophisticated things which now exist only for model systems can be made more practical with all of the other advances that are going on in algorithm development.
